qas.question: In what languages did Dante and Boccaccio create their works?
Which dialect became the norm for the modern Italian language?
What is one of Boccaccio's works that helped promote the Italian language?
Whose work, Canzoniere, is considered to be the first example of modern lyric poetry?
Who didn't wrote the Divine Comedy?
In what languages didn't Dante and Boccaccio create their works?
Which dialect became the norm for the ancient Italian language?
What is one of Boccaccio's works that helped demote the Italian language?
Whose work, Canzoniere, is considered to be the last example of modern lyric poetry?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>Dante Alighieri<b5_0/><a0_0/>'s Divine Comedy, written in the early 14th century, merged a medieval world view with classical ideals. Another promoter of the Italian language was Boccaccio with his <a3_0><b8_0>Decameron<b8_0/><a3_0/>. The application of the vernacular did not entail a rejection of Latin, and both Dante and Boccaccio wrote prolifically in <a1_0><b6_0>Latin as well as Italian<b6_0/><a1_0/>, as would <a4_0><b9_0>Petrarch<b9_0/><a4_0/> later (whose Canzoniere also promoted the vernacular and whose contents are considered the first modern lyric poems). Together the three poets established the <a2_0><b7_0>Tuscan<b7_0/><a2_0/> dialect as the norm for the modern Italian language.
